content.description:
For the first twenty feet of the route, climb steep bouldery moves up relatively good rock, using face holds and the occansional finger lock.

From here, the route continues to be steep, and larger holds appear to balance out the rapidly deteriorating rock quality and the various insects living in the crack.  Finish the route by showering your belayer with granite pebbles and wafers while pulling into an awkward v-shaped slot that allows you to reach the anchors.

A knee bar at twenty feet provides a rest, and a no hands rest can be found slightly higher.

The steepness (overhanging 25 feet in 40 feet of climbing) and opening moves of this route are it's only real redeeming features.  The fact that the Ruckman guide gives this route the same quality rating as many of the area's classics seems be mostly because one of the guide book authors was involved in the first ascent.
content.protection:
Bring a double set of cams from tips-sized through .75 Camalot.  Despite the short length of the route, the less than stellar rock quality encourages many placements.  The Ruckman guide mentions two fixed pins that are no longer present.

Anchors are two decent looking button heads with homemade hangers, currently equalized with some rope and a quick link.
content.location:
Park at the grist mill and thrash through scrub oak to get to the route.  See the photo topo of the Eagle buttress for the exact location.

Don't expect to have to wait in line to get on this one.

climbs.name: Strangeways
climbs.fa: Andy Ross, Gene Vallee, Shingo Ohkawa & Alex Quitiquit

content.description:
This is a great route which requires all the granite techniques. Deceptively steep and sustained, we thought it was going to be about 9+ when we first looked at it.

Four cruxes. Which one is harder? Depends on your technique.

Takes gear well, especially wires.
content.protection:
Set of wires, 1/2" to 3" cams and bolts.

Keep a 1/2",1" and 3" cams for between the two bolts. Little 5.6 runout at the top to the bolt anchor.
content.location:
This is on the lowest part of the crag, 20ft down and right of the obvious corner. Starts below a small tree stump.

See Shake it Up for directions to the crag.

climbs.name: Shake it Up
climbs.fa: Gene Vallee, Andy Ross & Tom Hore

content.description: A short, sustained slabby face with great moves.
content.location:
This is on the left side of the small crag up and right of the Ultra Lite Flight Crag and directly below Eagle Buttress.

Easiest approach is from Cabbage Patch up the hillside then veer right passing ULF. 20 min.

You can also come in from the old Gritmill which is closer but more of a bushwack. 15 min.

content.description: Fun 5.8 hand crack that begins wide with great jams and thins out up top. This climb made the bushwhack worthwhile.
content.protection: standard rack to #3, bolted anchor on top.
content.location: Shake It Up buttress. Park at the grit mill and find the path of least resistance. Look for the large roof as a landmark.

content.description:
A tricky move to establish yourself in the layback, a good edge and feet on the face for 30', and a final stem / mantle crux where the crack becomes a seam.

Sling the sail-like flake for a belay and downclimb the gully climber's left.

I pulled and kicked out a lot of loose rocks, so I think this is new. Pretty clean as of June 2019.
content.protection: Standard rack, heavier on fingers and small nuts for the mantle
content.location: The laser-cut crack immediately left of Ultralite Flight

content.description: Short, wide and loose grovel. Like climbing your friend's mom. Pro sucks and the last "well rooted" bush I slung as the only available pro fell out when my 2nd stood on it.
content.protection: Standard rack, take what you can get. No anchors, scramble down to top of Shake It Up to get down.
content.location: Shake It Up buttress. Park at the Grit Mill and wander up.

content.description: This route had been done before as there was a peg about 3/4 height and a bolted anchor on top.
content.protection: Standard rack, a few extra big cams.
content.location: The main corner on the cliff between Shake it Up and Strangeways,

content.description:
Mission to Moscow is the obvious right leaning crack.  Mostly hands with some funky stemming and chimneying possible to delay the pump.  Fight up to the squeeze chimney at the top, bust a move through the steep crack and a 3-bolt anchor awaits.

The Mission was thoroughly cleaned in June of 2008 and could use a regular ascent every now and then to keep it in a manageable condition.  With the amount of loose rock  that was brushed off/fell out of the crack, the star rating should be upped at least 1 star.  If there was a decent trail up to the base, it would probably earn another star.  Alright!  2 out of 3 stars ain't bad.
content.protection:
A double set would be more than enough.  Maybe an extra red and gold camalot would be nice.

Rap anchors at the top.
content.location: Up across from the Eagle Buttress.  Visible from the road.

content.description: Looking at the Eagle Buttress from the gully, this is the obvious wide crack in a dihedral.  A gorgeous line with enough potato-chip rock to make it a blast.  Belay at the tree at the base of the route.  Offwidth, chicken-wing and chimney your way up the dihedral.  Big cams are a must.
content.protection:
with 2 #6's an 2 #5's and singles from #2-4 camalots you should be set.

The book states there is a Fixed Pin and a bolt at the top but we only found one.
